channel.title: Recent & Upcoming Talks on Aravind Reddy
channel.description: Recent content in Recent & Upcoming Talks on Aravind Reddy

item.title: Space Bounded Complexity classes and Derandomization
item.description: In this talk, we will give an introduction to Space Bounded Complexity classes and give an overview of $BPL \subseteq \text{SPACE}(\log^2 n)$ result by Nisan. For space bounded complexity classes, we will follow the lecture notes by Prof. Luca Trevisan and for the $BPL \subseteq \text{SPACE}(\log^2 n)$ result, we will follow the lecture notes by Prof. Jonathan Katz.

item.title: High Dimensional Expanders
item.description: In this talk, we will give an introduction to High Dimensional Expanders, an area which has seen immense interest recently from the TCS community. Specifically, we will discuss Simplicial Complexes, Local Spectral Expanders, and Random walks on Simplicial Complexes.

item.title: Cup Games
item.description: In this talk, we will provide an introduction to cup games and discuss some recent results and techniques from a STOC 2019 paper by Bender et.al.

item.title: Markov Chains and Random Walks on Networks
item.description: The talk included 2 parts: A general introduction to Finite Markov Chains, and an introduction to Random walks on Networks(with their connection to electrical networks). The content for the talk was mostly from Chapters 1, 2, and 8 of the book Markov Chains and Mixing Times by David Levin and Yuval Peres.

item.title: Contrastive Unsupervised Representation Learning
item.description: The content for the talk was mostly taken from one of Arora et.al’s blog posts on offconvex.org and their paper A Theoretical Analysis of Contrastive Unsupervised Representation Learning. The first time I came across this paper was through a plenary talk given by Sanjeev Arora at ALT 2019.

item.title: Bilu-Linial Stable instances of Graph Partioniong problems
item.description: The content for the talk was mostly taken from the SODA’14 paper titled Bilu-Linial Stable Instances of Max Cut and Minimum Multiway Cut by Makarychev, Makarychev, and Vijayaraghavan. The presentation style and some of the examples were inspired by Tim Roughgarden’s lecture on the same topic.

item.title: Generalization theory for Deep Learning
item.description: The content for the talk was mostly taken from one of Sanjeev Arora’s blog posts on offconvex.org and Understanding deep learning requires re-thinking generalization, which won a Best Paper award at ICLR 2017.
